events.title: Birth
events.summary: Dietrich Buxtehude is thought to have been born with the name Diderich Buxtehude. Scholars dispute both the year and the country of his birth, although most now accept he was born in Helsingborg, Skåne, which was part of Denmark at that time.
events.fun_version: Dietrich Buxtehude, or Diderich if you’re feeling fancy, is believed to have popped into existence around a time of confusion – scholars can't even agree on when or where! Most think he was born in Helsingborg, Skåne, which was part of Denmark at that time.

events.title: Organist in Helsingborg
events.summary: Buxtehude was employed as an organist in Helsingborg, marking the beginning of his professional musical career.
events.fun_version: Buxtehude wasn’t just any ordinary musician; he got hired as an organist in Helsingborg, marking the beginning of his professional musical career, which was like finding the last slice of pizza at a party—absolutely delightful and the start of something cheesy!

events.title: Organist in Helsingør
events.summary: Buxtehude served as organist at St. Olaf's church in Helsingør, where he contributed to the musical tradition of the church.
events.fun_version: Buxtehude was not just an organist at St. Olaf's church in Helsingør; he was the wizard of the wooden keys! Picture him conjuring musical spells as the congregation tried not to fall asleep. His contributions to the musical tradition of the church? Let’s just say they could make a stone statue tap its feet!

events.title: Marriage to Anna Margarethe
events.summary: In 1668, Buxtehude married Anna Margarethe, the daughter of his predecessor Franz Tunder, continuing a tradition among organists.
events.fun_version: Back in 1668, Buxtehude tied the knot with Anna Margarethe, who's basically the royal heir of organ music since she’s the daughter of his predecessor, Franz Tunder! This love story not only sparked an organist soap opera but also continued enduring wedding traditions among organists! Who knew playing the organ was so romantic?

events.title: Establishment of Abendmusik
events.summary: Buxtehude reorganized the Abendmusik performances in Lübeck, a series of evening musical concerts that attracted musicians from various places.
events.fun_version: Buxtehude decided to give the evening concerts a fresh twist in Lübeck, reorganizing the Abendmusik performances, which attracted musicians from various places.

events.title: Meeting of Handel and Mattheson
events.summary: In 1703, both Handel and Mattheson traveled to meet the elderly Buxtehude, seeking insight and mentoring, although they declined his offer to marry his daughter and take his position.
events.fun_version: In 1703, both Handel and Mattheson decided to pay a visit to the ancient sage Buxtehude, hoping to snag some wisdom. Spoiler: they turned down his daughter’s hand in marriage, probably because they couldn’t find a suitable ring at the local ‘Ye Olde Jewelers’!

events.title: Bach's Visit
events.summary: In 1705, the young J.S. Bach walked over 400 kilometers to Lübeck to hear Buxtehude play and learn from him about his artistic techniques.
events.fun_version: In 1705, a young J.S. Bach must have had really strong legs because he walked over 400 kilometers to Lübeck just to hear Buxtehude play and learn about his artistic techniques! Who needs a car when your passion is to listen to someone else play the organ?
